thread.title: Air New Zealand accuses Qantas of acting like 'Air Sydney'
thread.title_full: Air New Zealand accuses Qantas of acting like 'Air Sydney' | afr.com

author: Jamie Freed
title: Air New Zealand accuses Qantas of acting like 'Air Sydney'
text:
Air NZ chief executive Christopher Luxon says: "In many ways you have got Qantas as Air Sydney rather than Air Australia." Mr Luxon said the number of Australian members of Air NZ's frequent flyer points program, Airpoints, had grown by 20 per cent over the past year and initial bookings from Australia on the Houston and Buenos Aires routes to be launched in December had exceeded expectations.
"Clearly we are selling very well out of Australia," he said. "We had quite a high mix in our business case there and we are selling above it."
Air NZ's push for more Australians on trans-Pacific flights could come partly at the expense of Virgin Australia Holdings, in which it owns a 25.99 per cent stake. Virgin offers direct flights from Sydney and Brisbane to Los Angeles, with domestic connections available from other cities.
'There are bits of Australia under-served' The reality for us is with Virgin we compartmentalise our relationship with them," Mr Luxon said, pointing to Virgin's alliance with Air NZ on trans-Tasman routes but Delta Air Lines on trans-Pacific routes."We look at it and we think there are bits of Australia under-served in connecting to North America and South America."
He said Virgin would benefit from Air NZ gaining more market share in Australia because that traffic was carried via trans-Tasman routes that are part of their alliance.
Documents filed by Qantas and American Airlines, which are seeking to deepen their trans-Pacific partnership, show Air NZ last year had a 5.7 per cent share of traffic between Australia and the US, including Hawaii, and a 10.8 per cent share of traffic between Australia and Canada.
Qantas and American have indicated the potential for American to begin flights on the Auckland-Los Angeles route as early next year, breaking Air NZ's monopoly on flights between New Zealand and North America.
Mr Luxon said Qantas and American carriers had previously struggled with the Auckland-Los Angeles route because it did not have as much business traffic as routes between the US and Australia.
"You have to understand leisure not corporate," he said. "We are comfortable taking on competition from any airline in the world."
He said Air NZ was examining additional new routes in North and South America. Qantas has signalled the potential to fly more routes from cities other than Sydney once it receives its new Boeing 787-9 aircraft from 2017 and chief executive Alan Joyce has mentioned Melbourne-Dallas as a possibility.
